analysis_result.description: The MQTT traffic reveals username 'admin' and password 'password123' transmitted in clear text. This exposes the system to unauthorized access if intercepted.
analysis_result.remediation: Implement TLS/SSL encryption for MQTT communication to protect credentials. Use strong, unique passwords and avoid default credentials.

analysis_result.description: The MQTT topic smart_home/light lacks adequate access controls or sanitization. Attackers could publish messages to control devices or inject malicious data.
analysis_result.remediation: Use a more robust topic structure with proper access control and sanitization. Employ message authentication to prevent tampering.

analysis_result.description: The data shows unencrypted TCP connections used for MQTT communication, which can expose sensitive information. Traffic is not protected and is vulnerable to interception and manipulation.
analysis_result.remediation: Utilize TLS/SSL to establish encrypted TCP connections. This will protect the data transmitted from eavesdropping.

analysis_result.description: The lack of encryption on the network communication makes it easy to perform MITM attacks, intercepting or altering data in transit. This is facilitated by unencrypted TCP and lack of certificate verification.
analysis_result.remediation: Implement mutual TLS/SSL authentication. Enforce strong cryptographic protocols, regularly review certificates, and ensure that all endpoints are securely configured.

analysis_result.description: The wireshark data shows checksum status (f190) as 0 for all TCP packets, meaning checksum validation is turned off or the data is not valid. This can be exploited to inject or alter TCP segments.
analysis_result.remediation: Enable checksum validation to protect against manipulated packets. This will ensure data integrity during communication.
